items.content_html:
Chrome makes the following types serializable (see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5745988251680768 ): DOMException, Error, EvalError, RangeError, ReferenceError, SyntaxError, TypeError, and URIError

Note, I can't find evidence that this is supported by Nodejs or deno.

This follows on from #16148

And it is technically part of the whole story in mdn/content#15638
items.title: Errors are serializable

items.content_html:
From #16148 (comment)

FF14 release notes say:

DOMException.code is now deprecated per latest DOM Level 4 specification.

The doc itself says:

returns a short that contains one of the error code constants, or 0 if none match. This field is used for historical reasons. New DOM exceptions don't use this anymore: they put this info in the DOMException.name attribute.

The spec refers to the Legacy code name and value - and it is the value that is in DOMException.code.

So I think that it is the case that this is not something code should rely on, even though the "deprecation" is at least 10 years old.
items.title: DOMException.code is deprecated

items.content_html:
These 3 non-standard interfaces have been added in Firefox 33 and there are not going away in the foreseeable future.

We have the corresponding pages on MDN and the lack of the bcd table lowers the amount of red near the bottom.

Addition in Gecko: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1006485 and https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1006485

Firefox 33 for developers

Note that we have bcd info for the corresponding non-standard entries for Chromium.
items.title: Add bcd info for IDBFileHandle, IDBMutableFile, and IDBFileRequest

items.content_html: This PR replaces some of our angle brackets in notes with HTML-formatted entities to ensure valid HTML throughout our notes.
items.title: Ensure our notes are HTML-formatted
